title: Motion Control of Robots: An Approach Based on Light Source Tracking
description: Bachelor’s thesis involving the design and construction of a 4-DOF bipedal robot capable of locomotion. The project included the full development of a light-tracking control system implemented on Arduino, from sensing to actuation.

details.challenge: The main challenge was designing a minimalistic yet effective strategy to let the robot follow a light source. Given limited sensing (only two photoresistors) and mechanical constraints, the task required translating light variations into directional commands—forward, left, or right—using simple hardware and control logic.
details.solution: A pair of photoresistors was mounted on the robot to measure light intensity. The control logic computed the difference between the two sensor readings to estimate the direction of the light source. This difference served as feedback for a simple reactive control scheme that decided whether the robot should move forward, turn left, or turn right.
